entries.description: This 2016 release reignited my inner 2006. New release coming next month.
I sit cross-legged when Serengeti tells stories. He is worth your attention. The letters defined in this song spell FUBU (×4), FILA, BOSS, PACO, JNCO, and USED.
The name, “Niney” refers to the thumb Winston Holness lost in an accident. Niney is one of Jamaica’s most revered producers. “Blood and Fire” was his first hit.
The story of Yup Juns was limited to three years due to the arrest of Shin Joong Hyun by South Korea’s authoritarian regime shortly after the release of their second record in 1975.

entries.album: Negro Prison Songs from the Mississippi State Penitentiary
entries.description: Led by a prisoner named, “22” this work song ends with an observation of the prison industrial complex. “Police get you and you workhouse bound.” Thank Alan Lomax for this 1958 recording.

I cannot put into words how much this performance affects me. I found it yesterday and wish I found it a long time ago. I have cried during every listen of this track. Stop whatever you are doing and give this your time. There is video of this historic album’s recording and its documentary form will be in theaters soon.
The New Orleans strut of this track begs you to move your body and you should oblige it. The Meters are considered by many as originators of funk.

entries.track: Something’s Got A Hold On Me
entries.description: Etta’s rawness is unmistakable. She has such a commanding presence that it is easy to overlook the entire choir on this track.

entries.track: How Long Do I Have To Wait For You?
entries.description: This introduction may be redundant, but it’s worth the risk. Sharon Jones released her first record at 40. Daptone’s first release was a Sharon Jones record. This track is one of the catchiest I have ever heard.

Charles Mingus was my entry point into jazz as an angsty teenage bassist. This composition is an elegy for saxophonist Lester Young. My initial exposure was to this later recording from 1963. The original is titled, “Goodbye Pork Pie Hat” on 1959’s, “Mingus Ah Um.”

entries.album: Sam Cooke With The Soul Stirrers
entries.track: Nearer To Thee - Live at the Shrine
entries.description: This live performance (The Great 1955 Shrine Concert) features an utterly untethered Sam Cooke and Paul Foster. The climax of this performance is hair-raising-ly palpable. It decidedly steps miles over the fine line Gospel music was walking at the time.

entries.album: One Night Stand - Sam Cooke Live At The Harlem Square Club, 1963
entries.track: Bring It on Home to Me
entries.description: RCA Victor slept on this record for 22 years. It didn’t fit the likeness of Sam Cooke that they were spinning to white audiences across the country. If this doesn’t hit you square in the feels, you are a dead person.
The hurried lyrical rhythm of this track perfectly describes what is both an adorably playful infatuation, and an infinitely desirable state of elation. From Detroit’s own Queen of Soul.

I don’t know what to do with this. I cried when I heard this song, then cried harder when I watched the music video. David Ruffin is sampled perfectly by producer Your Old Droog. It is supremely beautiful. This mixtape is amazing.
This album was released 13 years after Ruffin (The Temptations) died in 1991. It was recorded in the late 60’s. It was sampled in Westside Gunn’s, “Summer Slam 88.”
The sample closing out Earl’s, “Some Rap Songs,” and a prime piece from Hugh Masekela, the, “Father of South African jazz.”
The first producer Lester Bullock worked with was Lee “Scratch” Perry, who recommended the name change to, “Dillinger.” That is reason enough to listen to this song.

entries.album: Been in the Storm So Long - Spirituals & Shouts, Children's Game Songs, and Folktales
entries.description: This Folkways recording is of an isolated community living on Johns Island, SC — an area referred to by Alan Lomax as, “One of the heartlands of American music.” The entire record is shockingly potent, but this specific performance by Laura Rivers is exceptional.

entries.album: Kenya Special, Vol. 2 (Selected East African Recordings from the 1970’s & 80’s)
entries.description: I found myself listening to this weekly throughout 2018. “This world is coming to an end. This world is coming to an end. I can feel it. You can feel it. We all can feel it.”

entries.album: Beautiful Rivers and Mountains: The Psychedelic Rock Sound of South Korea’s Shin Joong Hyun 1958-1974
entries.description: Shin is referred to as Korea’s, “Godfather of Rock.” He protested a ‘72 military dictatorship and was imprisoned. His music was subsequently banned until the ‘80s.

entries.album: New Skin For The Old Ceremony
entries.description: Leonard Cohen makes me feel nostalgic about things that I have no business pretending to remember.
“And you think your country is a great democracy, Well they just killed your priest for helping folks like me.”
I don’t know anything about Anika, but this song makes me feel like the best kind of vampire. It uses tension remarkably well.
This is a tribute to O.D.B.’s “Snakes.” It will make you wish there was a complete Lee Fields cover of the sampled, “I’ll Never Do You Wrong” by Joe Tex.
No one needs my opinion of Frank. “You don’t know how little you matter until you’re all alone...”
I used to find this style of ‘80s production un-listenable, but this Trinidad & Tobago release from 1984 has made me second guess that notion entirely.

extra_links: NPR: The Tragic Turn Of The Frightnrs' First — And Last — Record
entries.description: Easily mistaken for 1968 Kingston, Jamaica. In reality it is 2016 Jamaica, Queens. This is, in a sense, a goodbye letter from singer Dan Klein. Dan succumbed to ALS three months prior to this Daptone release — hours after attending a Sharon Jones performance.
Limiting this vibe to 78 seconds is unfair to anyone that hears it. “Did I s...s...stutter, G?”
This track makes my face look like I am feeling a wad of bread dough in that game where you blindly stick your hand in a box and try to figure out what’s inside.
This is the sort of music I need more of.

entries.track: Anyone Who Knows What Love Is (Will Understand)
entries.description: Grab that special someone and slow dance with them. You don’t do it enough.

The first time I spent over $50 on a record. This song means everything to me. I found it when I first started developing my own musical taste. The single for “How Long” was the first Jamaican record to feature a string arrangement (overdubbed in UK release).
The song that got me into reggae. Good luck landing a copy of this version. I haven’t.

entries.album: Bunny “Striker” Lee’s Full Up: Early Reggae Productions 1968-72
entries.description: Find an alley, headphones on, hood up, and dance that pain away.

entries.album: I Love The Way You Love
entries.description: Name that sample. This is better.

entries.album: Elizabeth Cotten, Volume 3: When I’m Gone
entries.description: Dim the lights, sit in that chair you never sit in, light a cigarette, put this on loop, and close your eyes.
Apparently this song is a bluegrass standard, but I think it is actually everything.

entries.album: Every Time I Feel the Spirit
entries.description: Paul Robeson is always bigger than you think he is. He changed the words that he had sung countless times to ones that marked the spirit of his defiance. Boldly defying injustice while exercising remarkable kindness and compassion, Paul resounded in deep baritone across the nation. Everyone should learn the story of Paul Robeson.

entries.track: Ain't Got No - I Got Life
entries.description: Words do not describe the power of this song as it is performed here by Nina.

Donny effortlessly floats on top of a heavy D’Angelo-esque cadence in a straight-out-of-the-saloon-you-wish-existed live performance. In no reality would John Lennon come close to this. Another performance of this song is sampled in Chance’s “Juice”.
